Award.AwardTitle: Computational Methods for Structured and Singular Matrix Polynomials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Matrix polynomials frequently arise in the engineering and applied sciences,especially in structural dynamics, vibrational analysis, control systems, and differential-algebraic equations (DAEs), to give a few examples. Principal among the associated problems are the computation of the eigenstructure of regular matrix polynomials, and in the case of singular polynomials, the computation of minimal indices and minimal bases. In recent work, the investigators and their colleagues identified rich spaces of linearizations which led to the construction of new structured linearizations,condensed forms, and accurate structure-preserving algorithms. By using new techniques, they have also made progress on singular polynomials, showing that linearizations provide a pathway to the reliable computation of minimal indices and bases. This proposal singles out several important tasks for investigation concerning linearizations, quadratifications and minimal indices and bases. The goal is to develop new algorithms for these computations, and increase theoretical understanding so as to aid in the formulation of effective algorithms.

The problems studied in this proposal are ubiquitous in a wide range of important problems in engineering and applied sciences. Numerical methods for their solution are critical in structural mechanics, molecular dynamics, vibrational analysis, the simulation of electrical circuits, elastic deformation of anisotropic materials, and optical waveguide design, to give a few examples.
The trend towards extreme designs, such as high speed trains, optoelectronic devices, micro-electromechanical systems, and ``superjumbo'' jets such as the Airbus 380, presents a challenge for the computation of the resonant frequencies of these structures. These extreme designs often lead to computationally sensitive problems, while the physics of the underlying problem leads to structure that numerical methods should exploit in order to obtain physically meaningful results. The aim of this project is to increase our theoretical understanding of mathematical transformations that preserve these structures and thereby advance the development of computationally effective algorithms. Consequently, this work will have direct benefit to scientists and engineers across a wide range of disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Matrix polynomial eigenvalue problems occur in a wide range of important areas in engineering and the applied sciences, such as structural mechanics, molecular dynamics, vibrational analysis, the simulation of electrical circuits, elastic deformation of anisotropic materials, and optical waveguide design. Numerical methods for the accurate solution of polynomial eigenproblems are thus critical for many areas.

The physics of the underlying problem can lead to patterns or symmetries (alternating, palindromic,and Hermitian are among the most important) in the mathematical formulation of these eigenproblems, which are often computationally sensitive. When an iterative numerical method preserves these naturally occurring symmetries, it often produces physically more meaningful solutions. Thus the preservation of structural symmetries by numerical algorithms is an important objective.

This project has advanced this goal by increasing our knowledge of the mathematical transformations that preserve these structural symmetries. It has contributed a comprehensive theory of linear fractional transformations for matrix polynomials; this theory has already been successfully used by other researchers in the field.

The solution of an eigenvalue problem yields the resonant frequencies (spectrum) of a vibrating system. Numerical methods that attempt to solve a matrix polynomial eigenvalue problem typically do not work directly on the matrix polynomial. Instead, they convert the matrix polynomial into a related matrix expression of lower complexity but of much larger size, that has the same spectrum as the original matrix polynomial. This conversion process is called linearization. However, the methods available for this linearization process in software packages destroy the symmetries that may be present in the original matrix polynomial, because the palette of available linearizations has been limited.

This project studied the mathematical conditions under which a matrix polynomial with certain symmetries possesses a linearization that shares those same symmetries, thereby increasing our understanding of when it is possible or not possible to follow a structured linearization strategy. Also, new structured linearizations that are convenient to construct were discovered, thereby advancing the development of computationally effective algorithms.

Additionally, the project investigated linearizations for matrix polynomials expressed in different bases. Such polynomials arise as approximations to other more complicated non-linear eigenproblems. It was shown how to directly construct linearizations for matrix polynomials expressed in certain non-standard bases encountered in practice. This is a prerequisite for developing more accurate, linearization-based algorithms for such eigenproblems.

The establishment of a systematic understanding of the situations when structured linearizations are not possible, led to the development of a new idea – an alternative to linearization, called quadratification. This new notion was thoroughly explored, and many concrete examples constructed. It was shown that in all cases where structured linearizations fail to exist, a structured quadratification does exist. Thus the two notions (structured linearizations and structured quadratifications) together cover all the bases: every structured matrix polynomial (alternating, palindromic, Hermitian) has either a structured linearization or a structured quadratification, and sometimes has both.

Finally, the project furthered the training of a doctoral student who actively contributed to the research.
